comments.body: Could you explain why you need to add `(size.height - position.top - position.bottom) / 2.0` to the top offset? It makes my popup menu showing at a wrong place...
If you're seeing a problem with popup menus, please open a new issue and include a small test case that demos the problem. Happy to take a look!
Describe what this offset does and document that the default value is zero.

It's the offset applied to the popupMenu and not the button right?

```
The offset applied to the popup menu, relative to the button that opens it.

Defaults to [Offset.zero].
```
assert(offset != null)

comments.body: Describe what the shape would be if `PopupMenuThemeData.shape` was null as well.
Done
Describe what the color would be if `PopupMenuThemeData.color` was null as well.
Done
Why does the offset have to be set to zero here? I would assume that this would default to zero, but I'm unsure how this is set otherwise.
Even if it's zero by default; it seems helpful to make it clear that the child's origin aligns with the parent's origin.
Potentially this is simply personal preference. If you want, you can just revert this if you are a maintainer.

I believe this makes sense. It would necessarily be a breaking change since an assert statement was added (I would imagine some developers might have mistakenly defined both and this would break their application upon upgrade)
Also, it might be worth adding a regression test ensuring that an error is thrown when both have been defined.
It is not a **new** `assert`, sorry for the confusion. I only moved the description of the assertion from a comment into the `assert` call.
